newsitem.title: UK: Bookmakers count losses after Ascot record wins.
newsitem.headline: Bookmakers count losses after Ascot record wins.

text.p: Bookmakers counted their losses on Monday after jockey Frankie Dettori rocked the betting industry on Saturday as he beat the odds by riding all seven winning horses at the Ascot race track.
"This was the worst day in bookmaking history: our equivalent of a stock market crash, a real Black Saturday," spokesman Graham Sharpe of William Hill, part of Brent Walker Group Plc said.
The bookmaker lost eight million pounds and paid out over half a million pounds to one lucky gambler, Sharpe added.
Winning punter Darren Yates, who faced business collapse before Dettori's record-breaking feat, raked in 550,823.54 pounds on a 60 pound bet. "It just changes your whole life," he said.

The betting industry as a whole may have lost some 30 million pounds, Sharpe said. Betting shop group Stanley Leisure said the winning streak would hit its first-half results by some 2.25 million pounds.
Bookmakers tried to put on a brave face, saying that the betting industry would be boosted in the long-term by the extra publicity generated by Dettori's winning streak.
"Frankie Dettori has actually done the industry a lot of good," said a spokesman at bookmakers Ladbroke, which was still counting the money lost on Saturday.
"We have been hit, but we don't know yet by how much," the spokesman said.
